trans-unit.source: Hi! We are excited to have you play some games with us today!

You can use a mouse or touchpad to click your choice, you can use the arrow keys on your keyboard, or you can touch your screen if you are using a tablet. You can pick the way that works best for you.
If you have any questions or need help getting started, please ask the adult who is nearby to help you.

trans-unit.source:
In this game, you will do some math problems. Some will be like the ones you do in school and some will be a little different than what you do in school.
Some questions might be easy for you and some might be hard. That is okay! Please try your best and take your time. Most of the questions will have four choices. You choose the one you think is right. Let’s get started!

trans-unit.source: This is the Stories Game. In this game, you will listen to some stories. Then you will answer questions about the stories.
trans-unit.target: This is the Stories Game. In this game, you will listen to some stories. Then you will answer questions about the stories.

trans-unit.source: Nice work! Here is a new story.
trans-unit.target: Nice work! Here is a new story.

trans-unit.source: Here is Madison. This morning, Madison put her book behind the chair, because she didn’t want anyone to find it.
trans-unit.target: Here is Madison. This morning, Madison put her book behind the chair, because she didn’t want anyone to find it.

trans-unit.source: But when Madison was outside playing, someone did find it! And hid it under the rug.
trans-unit.target: But when Madison was outside playing, someone did find it! And hid it under the rug.

trans-unit.source: So now it’s reading time and Madison wants her book.
trans-unit.target: So now it’s reading time and Madison wants her book.

trans-unit.source: Where will Madison look first for her book?
trans-unit.target: Where will Madison look first for her book?

trans-unit.source: And where is her book really?
trans-unit.target: And where is her book really?

trans-unit.source: This morning when he came to school, Ethan put his book on the shelf above the coat hooks. Ethan’s book is blue!
trans-unit.target: This morning when he came to school, Ethan put his book on the shelf above the coat hooks. Ethan’s book is blue!

trans-unit.source: And then he went outside to play, see? Here’s Ethan playing outside. And while he was outside playing, Ethan’s book fell down from above the coat hooks onto the floor under the coats, see?
trans-unit.target: And then he went outside to play, see? Here’s Ethan playing outside. And while he was outside playing, Ethan’s book fell down from above the coat hooks onto the floor under the coats, see?

trans-unit.source: Then Hannah comes in and Hannah puts her book up above the coat hooks. Hannah's book is also blue! Ethan is still outside playing, so he didn't see what Hannah was doing.
trans-unit.target: Then Hannah comes in and Hannah puts her book up above the coat hooks. Hannah's book is also blue! Ethan is still outside playing, so he didn't see what Hannah was doing.

trans-unit.source: Now, when Ethan comes in from outside, where will he look first for his book?
trans-unit.target: Now, when Ethan comes in from outside, where will he look first for his book?

trans-unit.source: Let’s see what he does. Oh look, here is Ethan reaching for this book up on the shelf. And now Hannah sees Ethan reaching for that book... the book that is Hannah's!
trans-unit.target: Let’s see what he does. Oh look, here is Ethan reaching for this book up on the shelf. And now Hannah sees Ethan reaching for that book... the book that is Hannah's!

trans-unit.source: How do you think Hannah feels about Ethan reaching for that book?
trans-unit.target: How do you think Hannah feels about Ethan reaching for that book?

trans-unit.source: How do you think Hannah would feel if she had not seen Ethan reaching for the book?
trans-unit.target: How do you think Hannah would feel if she had not seen Ethan reaching for the book?

trans-unit.source: Is Ethan being mean and naughty for taking Hannah's book?
trans-unit.target: Is Ethan being mean and naughty for taking Hannah's book?

trans-unit.source: Should Ethan get in trouble with the teacher for taking Hannah's book?
trans-unit.target: Should Ethan get in trouble with the teacher for taking Hannah's book?

trans-unit.source: Can you help Hannah find her book? Is it on the shelf or under the coats?
trans-unit.target: Can you help Hannah find her book? Is it on the shelf or under the coats?

trans-unit.source: Can you help Ethan find his book? Is it on the shelf or under the coats?
trans-unit.target: Can you help Ethan find his book? Is it on the shelf or under the coats?

trans-unit.source: Joshua, Isabel, and Ivan are playing a game. Here's how the game goes: One kid hides, but draws a clue in the sandbox so the other kids can find them.
trans-unit.target: Joshua, Isabel, and Ivan are playing a game. Here's how the game goes: One kid hides, but draws a clue in the sandbox so the other kids can find them.

trans-unit.source: So Ivan is going first. He draws this clue in the sandbox, and then he goes to hide.
trans-unit.target: So Ivan is going first. He draws this clue in the sandbox, and then he goes to hide.

trans-unit.source: Now it's Joshua's turn to leave a clue, and hide. Isabel and Ivan will then try to use the clue to find him.
trans-unit.target: Now it's Joshua's turn to leave a clue, and hide. Isabel and Ivan will then try to use the clue to find him.

trans-unit.source: Joshua decides to hide behind the fountain. He draws a clue in the sand. He tries to draw the fountain, with the bottom part and the water coming out of it. But the drawing looks like a tree instead! Then Joshua goes and hides behind the fountain.
trans-unit.target: Joshua decides to hide behind the fountain. He draws a clue in the sand. He tries to draw the fountain, with the bottom part and the water coming out of it. But the drawing looks like a tree instead! Then Joshua goes and hides behind the fountain.

trans-unit.source: What did Joshua mean to draw?
trans-unit.target: What did Joshua mean to draw?

trans-unit.source: When Isabel and Ivan see this clue, where will they look first for Joshua?
trans-unit.target: When Isabel and Ivan see this clue, where will they look first for Joshua?

trans-unit.source: Can you help them find where Joshua really is?
trans-unit.target: Can you help them find where Joshua really is?

trans-unit.source: Look, Isabel and Ivan found Joshua, and won the game! How do you think Isabel feels about winning the game?
trans-unit.target: Look, Isabel and Ivan found Joshua, and won the game! How do you think Isabel feels about winning the game?

trans-unit.source: Now the games are over, and it's almost time to go home. Mother tells the kids to find all of their toys.
trans-unit.target: Now the games are over, and it's almost time to go home. Mother tells the kids to find all of their toys.

trans-unit.source: Joshua brought his toy truck with him to the park, but now he can't find it. He's looking everywhere but he can't find it.
trans-unit.target: Joshua brought his toy truck with him to the park, but now he can't find it. He's looking everywhere but he can't find it.

trans-unit.source: How does Joshua feel about losing his truck?
trans-unit.target: How does Joshua feel about losing his truck?

trans-unit.source: How would Joshua feel if he found his truck?
trans-unit.target: How would Joshua feel if he found his truck?

trans-unit.source: Joshua can't find his truck because earlier in the day, when no one was looking, Isabel took the toy truck and buried it in the sandbox.
trans-unit.target: Joshua can't find his truck because earlier in the day, when no one was looking, Isabel took the toy truck and buried it in the sandbox.

trans-unit.source: So Joshua looks everywhere and he can't find his toy truck. Mother gets mad at Joshua, because he lost his truck.
trans-unit.target: So Joshua looks everywhere and he can't find his toy truck. Mother gets mad at Joshua, because he lost his truck.

trans-unit.source: Is it fair that Mother is mad at Joshua for losing his truck?
trans-unit.target: Is it fair that Mother is mad at Joshua for losing his truck?

trans-unit.source: When Isabel sees that Mother is mad at Joshua, she goes to the sandbox and digs up the toy truck, and gives it back to Joshua.
trans-unit.target: When Isabel sees that Mother is mad at Joshua, she goes to the sandbox and digs up the toy truck, and gives it back to Joshua.

trans-unit.source: Is Mother mad at Joshua now?
trans-unit.target: Is Mother mad at Joshua now?

trans-unit.source: Is Mother mad at Isabel now?
trans-unit.target: Is Mother mad at Isabel now?

trans-unit.source: Is Joshua mad at Isabel now?
trans-unit.target: Is Joshua mad at Isabel now?

trans-unit.source: Isabel tells Joshua that she’s very sorry, and she gives him a big hug. Joshua gives her a big hug back, and Mother joins in.
trans-unit.target: Isabel tells Joshua that she’s very sorry, and she gives him a big hug. Joshua gives her a big hug back, and Mother joins in.

trans-unit.source: This is Katie. Earlier today, Katie's mom was cleaning the house, while Katie watched. Mom left three cups in the kitchen. There is a small cup on the counter, a medium sized cup on the table, and a big cup that she put away up high, on the shelf.
trans-unit.target: This is Katie. Earlier today, Katie's mom was cleaning the house, while Katie watched. Mom left three cups in the kitchen. There is a small cup on the counter, a medium sized cup on the table, and a big cup that she put away up high, on the shelf.

trans-unit.source: Katie and Dad just walked in and Katie asks her dad to get her a cup. Katie tells her Dad, “I want the big cup!”
trans-unit.target: Katie and Dad just walked in and Katie asks her dad to get her a cup. Katie tells her Dad, “I want the big cup!”

trans-unit.source: Which cup will Dad give Katie?
trans-unit.target: Which cup will Dad give Katie?

trans-unit.source: How does Katie feel about not getting the cup she wanted?
trans-unit.target: How does Katie feel about not getting the cup she wanted?

trans-unit.source: How would Katie feel if she had received the cup she wanted?
trans-unit.target: How would Katie feel if she had received the cup she wanted?

trans-unit.source: Sam and Maria are playing together. They look outside and see a new shop across the street. Maria tells Sam: “I am going to buy new shirts for us there,” and she walks away.
trans-unit.target: Sam and Maria are playing together. They look outside and see a new shop across the street. Maria tells Sam: “I am going to buy new shirts for us there,” and she walks away.

trans-unit.source: Mom comes home and she tells Sam that she just walked by the shop. “Are they selling shirts?” Sam asks. “No,” Mom says, “They are only selling shoes”. “Maria will probably now get shoes at the shop,” Sam says.
trans-unit.target: Mom comes home and she tells Sam that she just walked by the shop. “Are they selling shirts?” Sam asks. “No,” Mom says, “They are only selling shoes”. “Maria will probably now get shoes at the shop,” Sam says.

trans-unit.source: Does Maria know that they are selling shoes in the shop?
trans-unit.target: Does Maria know that they are selling shoes in the shop?

trans-unit.source: Maria has arrived at the shop. “I would like to buy shirts,” she says. “All we have left are socks,” says the shopkeeper. Since Maria also needs socks, she decides to get some socks.

trans-unit.source:
Thank you to you and your child for participating in this research project!

The following survey will take approximately 20-30 minutes to complete and will ask questions about your child.

When answering the questions, please think about your child who is participating in this research project. If you have more than one child participating in the research project, you will complete this survey separately for each participating child.

Some questions will note a specific timeframe to consider when answering. If no timeframe is indicated, you can think about how the answer applies to your child in general.

We appreciate you answering as completely and accurately as possible with the information you have available to you. If you have questions about this survey, please reach out to the research coordinator.

When you are ready to begin, select the “start survey” button.

Thank you!

trans-unit.source:
We are interested how often, independently, and easily your child shows each behavior when occasions call for it. Children who excel at a specific behavior should receive 4 (the highest rating), whereas most children will be between 3 and 2. Those who are still developing and need a lot of support should receive a rating of 1.

4 = Always on their own (No support needed)

3 = Mostly on their own (Brief reminders or support)

2 = Sometimes on their own (Regular reminders or moderate support needed)

1 = Not able on their own (Requires a lot of support)
trans-unit.target:

trans-unit.source: Completes activities that require multiple steps (e.g., fetching multiple things in home or store/market, setting the table, cleaning a room by putting several things away).
trans-unit.target: Completes activities that require multiple steps (e.g., fetching multiple things in home or store/market, setting the table, cleaning a room by putting several things away).

trans-unit.source: Comes up with new ways for solving challenges (e.g., repurposes materials or toys, comes up with a new way to build a tower or fort after it collapses, solves a puzzle in a new way, comes up with a new strategy to complete a chore).
trans-unit.target: Comes up with new ways for solving challenges (e.g., repurposes materials or toys, comes up with a new way to build a tower or fort after it collapses, solves a puzzle in a new way, comes up with a new strategy to complete a chore).

trans-unit.source: Identifies and gathers necessary materials before an activity (e.g., finds appropriate coat, shoes, hat before going outside; gathers lunch box, homework, and backpack before going to school).
trans-unit.target: Identifies and gathers necessary materials before an activity (e.g., finds appropriate coat, shoes, hat before going outside; gathers lunch box, homework, and backpack before going to school).

trans-unit.source: Finishes an assigned task that is repetitive (e.g., picking up toys, putting away laundry).
trans-unit.target: Finishes an assigned task that is repetitive (e.g., picking up toys, putting away laundry).

trans-unit.source: Completes an assigned task before moving to a next task.
trans-unit.target: Completes an assigned task before moving to a next task.

trans-unit.source: Stops an undesirable behavior when asked (e.g., stops fighting with sibling when asked by parent, stops misbehaving in the household).
trans-unit.target: Stops an undesirable behavior when asked (e.g., stops fighting with sibling when asked by parent, stops misbehaving in the household).

trans-unit.source: Completes activities that require remembering lengthy instructions (e.g., rules of a game, household chores, cooking recipe).
trans-unit.target: Completes activities that require remembering lengthy instructions (e.g., rules of a game, household chores, cooking recipe).

trans-unit.source: Expresses themselves in a new way when not understood by others (e.g., tries different ways to communicate their needs and wants).
trans-unit.target: Expresses themselves in a new way when not understood by others (e.g., tries different ways to communicate their needs and wants).

trans-unit.source: Creates a strategy or plan for completing a task (e.g., chore, homework, puzzle).
trans-unit.target: Creates a strategy or plan for completing a task (e.g., chore, homework, puzzle).

trans-unit.source: Remains focused and engaged during lengthy adult-led activities (e.g., religious or performance event, family meal time) by listening carefully and contributing when appropriate.
trans-unit.target: Remains focused and engaged during lengthy adult-led activities (e.g., religious or performance event, family meal time) by listening carefully and contributing when appropriate.

trans-unit.source: Regains focus/focuses again on an assigned task when interrupted (e.g., family member asks an unrelated question or needs brief assistance).
trans-unit.target: Regains focus/focuses again on an assigned task when interrupted (e.g., family member asks an unrelated question or needs brief assistance).

trans-unit.source: Stops playing or doing something fun when asked (e.g., stops playing with friends when parent asks, stops watching TV when parent asks).
trans-unit.target: Stops playing or doing something fun when asked (e.g., stops playing with friends when parent asks, stops watching TV when parent asks).

trans-unit.source: Communicates in an organized way (e.g., retells the correct sequence of the events, explains how a game works so it is easy to understand).
trans-unit.target: Communicates in an organized way (e.g., retells the correct sequence of the events, explains how a game works so it is easy to understand).

trans-unit.source: Adjusts when plans/schedules change (e.g., follows along when daily schedule changes, does not complain when unexpected sickness leads to canceling a family vacation).
trans-unit.target: Adjusts when plans/schedules change (e.g., follows along when daily schedule changes, does not complain when unexpected sickness leads to canceling a family vacation).

trans-unit.source: Finishes tasks on time (e.g., finishes homework on time and not at the last minute).
trans-unit.target: Finishes tasks on time (e.g., finishes homework on time and not at the last minute).

trans-unit.source: Remains focused and engaged during collaborative child-led activities (e.g., playing with siblings/peers).
trans-unit.target: Remains focused and engaged during collaborative child-led activities (e.g., playing with siblings/peers).

trans-unit.source: Ignores a preferred, fun activity (e.g., playing) when asked to complete an assigned task (e.g., cleaning room).
trans-unit.target: Ignores a preferred, fun activity (e.g., playing) when asked to complete an assigned task (e.g., cleaning room).

trans-unit.source: Waits for their turn to act (e.g., waits patiently in line at a grocery store or when sharing a toy with sibling).
trans-unit.target: Waits for their turn to act (e.g., waits patiently in line at a grocery store or when sharing a toy with sibling).

trans-unit.source: Completes age-appropriate numerical mental calculation (e.g., adds prices of goods, calculates time, how much they are older than someone else).
trans-unit.target: Completes age-appropriate numerical mental calculation (e.g., adds prices of goods, calculates time, how much they are older than someone else).

trans-unit.source: Understands conflicting perspectives/ideas (e.g., acknowledges a different point of view, accepts different ways of doing things, can see a situation from someone else's perspective).
trans-unit.target: Understands conflicting perspectives/ideas (e.g., acknowledges a different point of view, accepts different ways of doing things, can see a situation from someone else’s perspective).

trans-unit.source: Checks for mistakes before completing a task (e.g., reviews and corrects errors on class assignments).
trans-unit.target: Checks for mistakes before completing a task (e.g., reviews and corrects errors on class assignments).

trans-unit.source: Persists on a difficult cognitive/learning task (e.g., homework) by trying to figure things out, asking questions, and not quitting.
trans-unit.target: Persists on a difficult cognitive/learning task (e.g., homework) by trying to figure things out, asking questions, and not quitting.

trans-unit.source: Answers questions or tells a story without getting distracted by small details and/or losing train of thought.
trans-unit.target: Answers questions or tells a story without getting distracted by small details and/or losing train of thought.

trans-unit.source: Stops and thinks before acting (e.g., does not run out in front of a car, does not grab things they shouldn't).
trans-unit.target: Stops and thinks before acting (e.g., does not run out in front of a car, does not grab things they shouldn't).

trans-unit.source: Remembers and considers all options when making a choice (e.g., what to do when they get stuck on a household task or face a problem, food options).
trans-unit.target: Remembers and considers all options when making a choice (e.g., what to do when they get stuck on a household task or face a problem, food options).

trans-unit.source: Connects ideas/experiences to other ideas/experiences (e.g., identifies connections between books/movies and lived experiences, uses strategies learned at school to complete activities at home).
trans-unit.target: Connects ideas/experiences to other ideas/experiences (e.g., identifies connections between books/movies and lived experiences, uses strategies learned at school to complete activities at home).

trans-unit.source: Begins plans or routines without prompting (e.g., takes an initiative to help a family member, starts daily household chores on their own).
trans-unit.target: Begins plans or routines without prompting (e.g., takes an initiative to help a family member, starts daily household chores on their own).

trans-unit.source: Gets deeply engaged in an activity they choose for themselves (e.g., drawing, reading, cooking, building, sports, games).
trans-unit.target: Gets deeply engaged in an activity they choose for themselves (e.g., drawing, reading, cooking, building, sports, games).

trans-unit.source: Remembers physical directions, patterns, and where things are (e.g., knows walking routes, finds things in a grocery store, good at searching for a lost item or playing hide-and-seek).
trans-unit.target: Remembers physical directions, patterns, and where things are (e.g., knows walking routes, finds things in a grocery store, good at searching for a lost item or playing hide-and-seek).

trans-unit.source: Adapts behavior based on what is required by the situation (e.g., switches characters/roles while playing a game, changes behavior based on playtime or study time).
trans-unit.target: Adapts behavior based on what is required by the situation (e.g., switches characters/roles while playing a game, changes behavior based on playtime or study time).

trans-unit.source: Negotiates and incorporates peers' suggestions without conflict or resistance (e.g., works with others to plan roles during pretend play, negotiates with sibling about how to complete chores together).
trans-unit.target: Negotiates and incorporates peers' suggestions without conflict or resistance (e.g., works with others to plan roles during pretend play, negotiates with sibling about how to complete chores together).

trans-unit.source:
Thank you again for participating in this research project!

The following survey will take approximately 20-30 minutes to complete and will ask questions about your home and yourself.

We appreciate you answering as completely and accurately as possible with the information you have available to you. If you have questions about this survey, please reach out to the research coordinator.

When you are ready to begin, select the “start survey” button.

Thank you!
trans-unit.target:

trans-unit.source:
Instructions:<\/b> Think of this line as representing where people stand in the country where you live<\/i>. To the right<\/b> are the people who are the best off - those who have the most money, the most education, and the most respected jobs. To the left<\/b> are the people who are the worst off - those who have the least money, the least education, the least respected jobs, or no job. The further to the right you are on the line, the closer you are to the people at the very top; the further to the left you are, the closer you are to the people at the very bottom.
Where would you place yourself on this line?<\/b>
Move the slider to where you think you stand at this time in your life relative to other people in your country.
trans-unit.target:

In Part B the questions are classroom specific. If you teach more than one class of students included in this project, you will complete Part B separately for each classroom.

If you teach a single subject, please complete the questions that relate to other subjects to the best of your knowledge or consult with a colleague for those details only.

When you are ready to begin, select the "Next" button.

Thank you!

trans-unit.source:
Thank you for taking the time (~10 minutes) to respond to this survey!

Some students you teach are participating in a research project studying how children learn and develop. Your responses in this survey should apply to your classroom, school, and professional beliefs rather than to any specific child.

This survey has two parts: Part A and Part B.

In Part A, the questions relate to your background and beliefs.

In Part B, the questions are specific to your classroom. If you teach more than one class included in this project, you will complete Part B separately for each.

If you teach a single subject, please complete questions that relate to other subjects to the best of your knowledge or consult a colleague for those details only.

Thank you for your participation! Your responses provide invaluable insight into the education of your students.

When you are ready to begin, select the "Start Survey" button.

Thank you!
trans-unit.target:
